title: My brother beat the s**t out of me
text:
Share on Twitter 
OLYMPIC swimming champion Grant Hackett has taken a sensational swipe at his brother who dubbed him “dangerous” in the wake of his arrest claiming he “beat the shit” out of him. 
Posting an image of himself on Instagram sporting an angry black eye, the triple Olympic gold medallist made the unsubstantiated claim: “My brother comments to the media… Does anyone know he beat the shit out of me? 
“Everyone knows he is an angry man.” 
In remarkably candid comments to the media yesterday, Craig Hackett said the family had finally cracked under pressure and could no longer cope with his “dangerous” behaviour. 
His parents called police who arrested him at their Gold Coast home saying he had suffered a “mental breakdown”. 
“We’ve reached the end of the road,” his brother said. Grant Hackett’s brother Craig speak to the media yesterday. Photo: David Clark   
“He had the world at his feet … such a role model to so many kids … and now no one knows what’s going to happen. It doesn’t look encouraging. 
“It’s coming to the point now where he is dangerous. He’s a danger to himself, he’s a danger to the community, and poor Mum and Dad have tried to look after him so much. I’m concerned for their welfare.” A handcuffed Hackett gives a thumbs up to the media after his arrest. Picture: Channel 7 Source: Channel 7 
Hackett, 36, was arrested at his parents’ house in Mermaid Waters on Wednesday after flying into a rage, and is now being treated in hospital. 
His father Neville said calling the police was the only option he had while Hackett’s brother said the family were supporting him but had run out of options. 
A family member ­recently took a court order against the athlete that expires in January 2019, requiring him to be of “good behaviour” until then. Grant Hackett leaves Southport Watchhouse yesterday following his arrest. Picture: Jerad Williams   
“This is now a chronic problem and it looks like it’s not going to go away in a hurry,’ Craig said. 
‘The whole family have been doing all that we can but now it’s kind of out of our hands, it really is. 
“The Grant Hackett that Australia fell in love with, they can still have that affection towards him. 
‘(But) this is not Grant Hackett. This is a completely different person. I don’t know this person, my mum and dad don’t know this person. 
“He’s there in body, but he’s not there in mind, soul or spirit. 
“We can’t do it. It’s getting to the point where he’s dangerous. He’s a danger to himself and to the community.” 
Hackett, a three-time Olympic gold medallist and considered to be one of Australia’s greatest swimmers, has struggled with personal issues and addiction. 
He attempted to make the team for Rio last year but missed out, only to be involved in a drunken incident on the flight back from Adelaide and was detained by police. 
In 2014, he was filmed walking around The Crown Casino in his underwear claiming to be looking for his young son. That lead to a five-week stint in rehab. 
Hackett has made little secret that he had struggled to adjust after professional sport and this latest incident comes as a huge setback in his efforts to reform his life. 
He spent time in a US rehab clinic where he was treated for a sleeping pill addiction after photos emerged of him wandering around looking lost with a singlet wrapped around his waist as a pair of shorts.
